results.title: Aboriginal History Archive
results.brief_description: The Aboriginal History Archive is Australia’s first collection of resources that documents the Black Power movement, resists colonial narratives and celebrates self-determination. Activists of the era saw the power of film and TV to tell truth, advocate for justice and resist oppression.

constellations_primary.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_primary.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

results.description:
The Aboriginal History Archive is Australia’s first collection of resources that documents the Black Power movement, resists colonial narratives and celebrates self-determination. Featuring thousands of photos, videos, campaign materials, media and manuscripts, it aims to reinterpret and reframe Australia’s Aboriginal political history.

Activists of the era saw the power of film and television to tell truth, advocate for justice and resist oppression, as well as galvanise other First Peoples into action. Their involvement in films, documentaries and later, during the 1980s, television, inadvertently allowed activists to champion the rights of First Peoples while simultaneously increasing representation in screen culture.
description_for_label:
The Aboriginal History Archive is Australia’s first collection of resources that documents the Black Power movement, resists colonial narratives and celebrates self-determination. Featuring thousands of photos, videos, campaign materials, media and manuscripts, it aims to reinterpret and reframe Australia’s Aboriginal political history.

Activists of the era saw the power of film and television to tell truth, advocate for justice and resist oppression, as well as galvanise other First Peoples into action. Their involvement in films, documentaries and later, during the 1980s, television, inadvertently allowed activists to champion the rights of First Peoples while simultaneously increasing representation in screen culture.

results.title: A Bill of Divorcement cinema slide
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures and George Cukor
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Slide imagery with a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: RKO Radio Pictures presents John Barrymore in A Bill of Divorcement A play that ran a solid year in London and New York with Katharine Hepburn Billie Bourk David Manners Barrymore in the biggest story and finest part of his brilliant career.

results.title: 2000 Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature model celebrates memorable moments from the 2000s.

constellations_primary.name: 2000s TV
constellations_primary.description: The dawn of the new millennium brought a wave of Australian programming that was more ambitious and bolder than previous decades.

results.description: It’s noice, it’s different, it’s unusual. Gina Riley and Jane Turner’s hugely popular Kath & Kim hit screens in 2002, poking fun at Aussie suburbia and spawning a trend of mockumentary-style sitcoms. Meanwhile another female-driven show The Secret Life Of Us was breaking boundaries on Channel 10: Deborah Mailman’s casting was a landmark moment for representation of Indigenous Australians in mainstream media. The hit series also acted as a training ground for a whole wave of prominent female filmmakers like Cate Shortland, Ana Kokkinos and Emma Freeman. Public broadcasters SBS and ABC had very different successes with East West 101 for the former – a multicultural police procedural – and animated series Bluey becoming a global phenomenon for the latter.
description_for_label: It’s noice, it’s different, it’s unusual. Gina Riley and Jane Turner’s hugely popular Kath & Kim hit screens in 2002, poking fun at Aussie suburbia and spawning a trend of mockumentary-style sitcoms. Meanwhile another female-driven show The Secret Life Of Us was breaking boundaries on Channel 10: Deborah Mailman’s casting was a landmark moment for representation of Indigenous Australians in mainstream media. The hit series also acted as a training ground for a whole wave of prominent female filmmakers like Cate Shortland, Ana Kokkinos and Emma Freeman. Public broadcasters SBS and ABC had very different successes with East West 101 for the former – a multicultural police procedural – and animated series Bluey becoming a global phenomenon for the latter.
results.credit_line_for_label: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun

results.title: 1990s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature TV model celebrates the evolving living rooms of Australians and beloved TV from the 1990s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_primary.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

results.description: Skippy had stiff competition for the title of Australia’s most beloved (and fictional) marsupial when Blinky Bill debuted in 1993. Based on Dorothy Wall’s books, the animated series incorporated environmental messages into its storylines and saw film and video game spin-offs. The analysis of Australian politics got satirical with Frontline, as local TV began to stretch the possibilities of what it could do creatively. While Home & Away was finding mainstream success, teenage soap Heartbreak High premiered in 1994 and tackled heady subjects for the time including racism, homelessness, drug addiction and sexuality. Crucially, it also introduced the phrase “rack off” into the pop-cultural lexicon.
description_for_label: Skippy had stiff competition for the title of Australia’s most beloved (and fictional) marsupial when Blinky Bill debuted in 1993. Based on Dorothy Wall’s books, the animated series incorporated environmental messages into its storylines and saw film and video game spin-offs. The analysis of Australian politics got satirical with Frontline, as local TV began to stretch the possibilities of what it could do creatively. While Home & Away was finding mainstream success, teenage soap Heartbreak High premiered in 1994 and tackled heady subjects for the time including racism, homelessness, drug addiction and sexuality. Crucially, it also introduced the phrase “rack off” into the pop-cultural lexicon.
